Approved for Public Release;Distribution Unlimited. Case Number 17-0645
. | # | | # | 
 
Task Description: FAA Sponsored Independent R&D
Objective:
Examine the feasibility and best practices for developing and distributing SWIM-based applications via an open source software model. FAA Sponsor:
FAA Mission-Oriented Investigation and Experimentation program.
Paul Fontaine, Portfolio Management and Technology Development, Office of NextGen. Planned activities:
Examine current uses for SWIM data in public and private sectors.
Examine technologies and best practices to support open source development and implementation.
Implement an initial open source SWIM site and develop user community. End product:
Recommendations to the FAA SWIM Program office for standardizing data processing and associated analytic capabilities
Best practices for accelerating development and technology transfer
Open source SWIM site and associated software capabilities | # | 
 
Presidential Memorandum Promoting Use of Open Source Software Establishes a pilot program directing agencies commissioning custom software to: Release at least 20 percent of new custom-developed code as Open Source Software (OSS) for three years Collect additional data concerning new custom software to inform metrics to gauge the performance of this pilot
Brands and logos may be trademarked by their respective holder(s). | # | 
 
What is System Wide Information Management? SWIM Terminal Data Distribution Service (STDDS)
Weather And Radar Processor (WARP)

Traffic Flow Management (TFMData)
SWIM Flight Data Publication (SFDPS)

Airlines, Research organizations, ANSPs, FAA contractors, and more Image Source: https://www.faa.gov/nextgen/programs/swim/overview/

 5 Availability of the source code enables re-use
Not a black-box
Clarity and trust
Ability to debug
Users contribute improvements code is more reliable
Usage, modification, and redistribution controlled by license
Developer retains the copyright
Violations of the license infringes copyright

Mozilla
Android
HDFS
Apache

The Open Source Software Model | # | 
 6 Expected Outcome
Promote development and distribution of SWIM-based applications via an open source software model | # | 
 7 Standardize data processing and interpretation utilities Reduce development time and cost of application development Lower entrance barrier, enabling innovative end-user applications Promote tech transfer by reusing prototypes, lowering acquisition cost Develop a MITRE open source model / license (Apache)
Survey current SWIM data usages in public and private sectors
Identify the best open source practices
Develop licensing options
Identify best technologies to support implementation Implement the initial capabilities of SWIM Open Source site (e.g. GitHub, JIRA) Develop and distribute an initial Open Source SWIM software package
Be modular, i.e., individual parts are useful without access to all feeds
Develop initial libraries
Connect to feed
Associate data elements (e.g., TFMS + STDDS integrated flight object)
Common geometric, trigonometric, navigational
Common GUI / Visualization Components Outreach to internal/external SWIM data users Technical Approach | # | 
 8 Layered API Design
Objectives of Component Design:
Protect components from changes in SWIM feeds
Re-use data structures
Re-use algorithms
Make components agnostic to real-time / replay
Encourage use of single configuration process
Integrated status monitoring / logging
Make components agnostic to file / stream input
Support archiving, live operation, replays, data pre-loading
Promote code re-use / modularity | # | 
 GUI Web Server Application Specific Processing Algorithmic Data Management SWIM Feed Processing Foundation Classes Examples of Reusable Components for SWIM Applications 
Connectivity:
SWIM Client APIs
SWIM Feed Services
Data Management:
Flight Data API

ATC Facility API
Algorithmic Processing:
Holding Detection Algorithm
Diversion Detection Algorithm
Airport Demand Prediction Algorithm

Airport Taxi Activity Monitor
Visualization:
Airport Taxi Status GUI
Airport Status GUI

 10 Intended Impact
Standardize data processing and interpretation utilities for government and industry users Significantly reduce the cost and expedite the process of developing new automation
Lower entrance barriers
Focus on innovative end-user applications Facilitate the development and tech transfer of software prototypes
Development of a common software foundation based on SWIM would enable ready conversion of prototypes to operational systems. | # | 
 11 FY17 Milestones
Review current industry best practices for open source model Identify needs and user groups of SWIM-enabled applications Meet with FAA SWIM office, flight operators, and contractors to identify current and future SWIM program plans and planned uses of SWIM data Define requirements of the open source software platform Implement initial open source capabilities Conduct outreach SWIM user groups and build the community | # | 
 12 Promoting SWIM through Open Source Software Development
Objective:
Create an Open Source Community of SWIM users (research organizations, airlines, 
 commercial contractors, ANSPs) centered around software used to process FAA SWIM data
Expected Results:
Improve quality and interoperability of FAA software by standardizing data processing and interpretation
Reduce software development costs for FAA prototypes by enabling re-use
Encourage SWIM usage by lowering barriers to entry for new participants
Lower FAA acquisition costs by facilitating direct tech transfer of research prototypes to operational systems
Actions:
Identify best practices for Open Source development:
Technologies: Github, JIRA, Atlassian toolkit, Java, JavaScript, JMS, Web Services
Establish rules for managing releases and contributions from multiple organizations
Identify Open Source license terms (e.g., Apache OS License)
Develop and release modular, object-oriented software to process SWIM data
Outreach:
FAA: Coordinate with FAA SWIM and open source software
Airlines, research organizations and ANSPs: Determine current and planned uses for SWIM data and develop open source community
Dovetails with FAA Federal Source Policy by:
Channeling new software development to produce re-usable, open source software so that the benefits of FAA policy and SWIM investment are fully realized
